fr.sorbonne_u.devs_simulation.hioa.models.vars.histories

Class ValueHistory<Type>

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sorbonne_u.devs_simulation.hioa.models.vars.histories.ValueHistory<Type>
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    PiecewiseInterExtrapolatedValueHistory

    public class ValueHistory<Type>
extends java.lang.Object
    The class ValueHistory implements a history mechanism for model variables to memorise its most recent values over a predefined time sliding window in a buffer.

    Description

    The history mechanism is initially defined with a bounded capacity and then values can be pushed into the history managed as a bounded buffer which values can be accessed from the most recent with index 0 to the least recent with index getCurrentSize(). This decreasing time order has been chosen to speed up accesses to the latest values, which are forecasted to be the ones most often accessed in practice.

    When beginning to use the history object, the number of memorised values will gradually increase with the calls to add. After each add, the history is trimmed to the chosen time window to drop the oldest values.

    Value histories need not be thread safe, as each ValueHistory instance will be assumed to be owned by one and only one other object (here Value instances). Hence, the thread-safe property is implemented by the owner object, first by confining the reference to its ValueHistory instance inside itself and then by accessing this ValueHistory instance in a thread-safe manner.

    Glass-box Invariants

     invariant       historyWindow != null && historyWindow.greaterThan(Duration.zero(historyWindow.getTimeUnit()))
 invariant       isInAscendingOrderOfTime()}

    Black-box Invariants

     invariant       true        // no more invariant

    Created on : 2018-09-06

    Author:
    Jacques Malenfant

      create a new value history with an infinite time window; beware that an infinite time window means that an unbounded number of values will be kept in the history.

      • add

        public void add(Value<Type> value)
        add a value to the history, this value becoming its newest one.

        Contract

         pre     value != null
 pre     getCurrentSize() == 0 || value.getTime().getTimeUnit().equals(getTimeUnit())
 pre     getCurrentSize() == 0 || value.getTime().greaterThan(getCurrentTime())
 post    getCurrentSize() >= 1
        Parameters:
        value - value to be added to the history.

         pre     true        // no precondition.
 post    getCurrentSize() == 0

      • trimToWindow

        public void trimToWindow()
        delete all values in the history that are too old to be in the history time window but leave at least one value if there was one nor more before the trim.

        Contract

         pre     true        // no precondition.
 post    getCurrentSize()_at_pre == 0 || getCurrentSize() > 0

      • evaluateAt

        public Type evaluateAt(Time t)
        return the value at the time t; if no value corresponds exactly to t, this implementation interpolates to the most recent value in the history which time is lower or equal to t i.e., a simple piecewise constant interpolation/extrapolation is used; if t is lower than the time of the oldest value in the history, the oldest value is returned i.e., a simple constant extrapolation to the past is used.

        Contract

         pre     getCurrentSize() > 0
 pre     t != null && t.getTimeUnit().equals(getTimeUnit())
 post    true        // no postcondition.
        Parameters:
        t - time at which the value is required.
        Returns:
        the value at the time t.
